title-group.article-title: Participation in a Medicare advanced primary care model and the delivery of high‐value services

aff.institution: Institute for Advanced Analytics, North Carolina State University

aff.named-content: Department of Medical Ethics & Health Policy
aff.institution: Perelman School of Medicine, University of Pennsylvania

author-notes.corresp: *Correspondence Fang He, Ph.D., RTI International, 3040 East Cornwallis Road, P.O. Box 12194, Research Triangle Park, NC, 27709, USA. Email: fhe@rti.org

sec.title: Objective
sec.p: To evaluate whether primary care providers' participation in the Comprehensive Primary Care Plus Initiative (CPC+) was associated with changes in their delivery of high‐value services.

sec.title: Data Sources
sec.p: Medicare Physician & Other Practitioners public use files from 2013 to 2019, 2017 to 2019 Medicare Part B claims for a 5% random sample of Medicare Fee‐for‐Service (FFS) beneficiaries, the Area Health Resources File, the National Plan & Provider Enumeration System files, and public use datasets from the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services Physician Compare.

sec.title: Study Design
sec.p: We used a difference‐in‐difference approach with a propensity score‐matched comparison group to estimate the association of CPC+ participation with the delivery of annual wellness visits (AWVs), advance care planning (ACP), flu shots, counseling to prevent tobacco use, and depression screening. These services are prominent examples of high‐value services, providing benefits to patients at a reasonable cost. We examined both the likelihood of delivering these services within a year and the count of services delivered per 1000 Medicare FFS beneficiaries per year.

sec.title: Data Collection/Extraction Methods
sec.p: Secondary data are linked at the provider level.

sec.title: Principal Findings
sec.p: We find that CPC+ participation was associated with increases in the likelihood of delivering AWVs (13.03 percentage points by CPC+'s third year, p < 0.001) and the number of AWVs per 1000 Medicare FFS beneficiaries (44 more AWVs by CPC+'s third year, p < 0.001). We also find that CPC+ participation was associated with more flu shots per 1000 beneficiaries (52 more shots by CPC+'s third year, p < 0.001) but not with the likelihood of delivering flu shots. We did not find consistent evidence for the association between CPC+ participation and ACP services, counseling to prevent tobacco use, or depression screening.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: CPC+ participation was associated with increases in the delivery of AWVs and flu shots, but not other high‐value services.

p.mixed-citation: HeF, GasdaskaA, WhiteL, TangY, BeadlesC. Participation in a Medicare advanced primary care model and the delivery of high‐value services. Health Serv Res. 2023;58(6):1266‐1291. doi:10.1111/1475-6773.1421337557935PMC10622300

sec.title: What is known on this topic

list-item.p: The Comprehensive Primary Care Plus Initiative (CPC+) was the nation's largest ever model to transform primary care by tying provider payments to the primary care provided to patients.

CPC+ prioritized annual wellness visits (AWVs) in its methodology to attribute beneficiaries to providers and also provided other supports that may have encouraged the delivery of high‐value services.
A previous study found that participation in the Medicare Shared Savings Program was associated with increases in the delivery of some preventative services, including flu shots and AWVs.
This is the first study to examine the effect of CPC+ participation on delivery of high‐value services, helping to illuminate the effect of various policy levers in encouraging their delivery.
We find that CPC+ participation is associated with increased delivery of AWVs and flu shots, though not other high‐value services.
CPC+'s prioritization of AWVs in its beneficiary attribution methodology provided an explicit incentive to deliver AWVs and may have been a key contributor to the increase in AWVs.

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: High‐value services provide benefits to patients at a reasonable cost and should be encouraged for all patients with specific medical conditions. 1 Prominent examples include Medicare's annual wellness visits (AWVs), advance care planning (ACP), and preventative services such as flu shots, counseling to prevent tobacco use, and depression screening. Medicare's AWV, introduced in 2011, is an annual check‐up that includes screening for depression, detection of cognitive impairment, and planning for other preventive services. 2 AWVs have been shown to increase the delivery of other preventive services, increase diagnoses of dementia, and reduce health care spending. 3 , 4 , 5 , 6 ACP, which Medicare began reimbursing in 2016, is planning that aligns the care an individual wants to receive if they become unable to speak for themselves with their values and goals. 7 Many studies have demonstrated associations between ACP and improvements in the quality of end‐of‐life care. 8 , 9 Flu shots, counseling to prevent tobacco use, and depression screening have been shown by many studies to either decrease cost or be cost‐effective (i.e., benefits exceed costs). These services are also recommended by the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force and, like AWVs, are deemed by the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) as important enough to waive beneficiary cost‐sharing. 10 , 11 , 12

Despite their high value and CMS's efforts to encourage their delivery, the use of these services is suboptimal. 7 , 13 , 14 , 15 , 16 In addition, studies have shown lower use among Medicare beneficiaries who are of non‐White race, male, lower income, less educated, and enrolled in Medicaid. 16 , 17 , 18 , 19 , 20 , 21 Obstacles to using AWVs include Medicare's complex and sometimes confusing billing requirements. This may especially deter providers caring for underserved or rural populations from delivering these services since they may have greater workload or difficulty filling clinical positions to help provide AWVs. 22 For ACP, challenges include relatively low payment rates and unclear billing requirements. 7 Obstacles to using other preventative services include limits on beneficiary–provider encounter time, which often focuses on the diseases that triggered the visit, rather than discussing risk factors such as tobacco use or depression. 18 , 19 , 23 , 24

Explicitly incentivizing high‐value services within Medicare alternative payment models may be one solution to overcoming some of these obstacles. Huang et al (2022) found that participating in the Medicare Shared Savings Program (MSSP), Medicare's largest alternative payment model, was associated with increased delivery of preventative services. 25 Another prominent Medicare alternative payment model is the Comprehensive Primary Care Plus Initiative (CPC+). CPC+ was the nation's largest ever primary care transformation model and was an expansion of a previous model, the Comprehensive Primary Care Initiative (CPC Classic). Through 2021, CPC+ included almost 3000 primary care practices and around 2 million Medicare Fee‐for‐Service (FFS) beneficiaries. CPC+ included two tracks: one track that paid providers performance‐based payments and fixed monthly payments to manage the care of each beneficiary and another track that also partially capitated a provider's primary care payments. 26 CPC+ started in 2017 in 14 regions and expanded to four additional regions in 2018. Practices in these regions applied to CPC+ and were selected by CMS based on whether they, for example, primarily provided primary care services. 27 Compared with non‐CPC+ practices, CPC+ practices were larger, more likely to be integrated into a health system, more likely to have some experience with care transformation, and served Medicare FFS beneficiaries who were slightly healthier and more advantaged. 28 , 29 , 30

This study examines the impact of participating in the CPC+ partial capitation track on the delivery of AWVs, ACP, and other preventive services. While previous studies have evaluated the impact of CPC+, we are the first to examine the effect of CPC+ on the delivery of high‐value services. 31 , 32 , 33 , 34 , 35 In addition, we build on Huang et al (2022)'s examination of the relationship between MSSP participation and delivery of preventative services. 25 Because of differences between CPC+ and MSSP, examining CPC+ can help illuminate which levers alternative payment models can use to increase the delivery of high‐value services.

sec.title: Study design
sec.p: We used a propensity score matching and difference‐in‐difference approach to estimate the effects of CPC+ participation on the delivery of AWVs, ACP, and other preventative services. In the intervention group, we included providers who participated in CPC+ every year from 2017 through 2019 in the 14 regions in which CPC+ started in 2017. Excluding providers participating in CPC+ for only a subset of these years limits our ability to generalize results to providers who exited CPC+ prematurely. However, it avoids introducing potential biases from including providers who exited due to reasons, such as having only a few Medicare FFS patients, that may be associated with our outcomes. For simplicity of design and interpretation, we also excluded CPC+ providers in the four regions in which CPC+ started in 2018. These excluded providers were only 8% of all CPC+ providers. 31 Finally, we excluded CPC+ providers who did not have significant billing to Medicare Part B (defined as billing at least one service for more than 10 beneficiaries) in any years from 2013 to 2019. We used propensity score matching to construct a comparison group.

We further divided the intervention group into two subgroups: providers in the regions part of CPC Classic (which we refer to as the CPC Classic subgroup) and providers in other regions in which CPC+ began in 2017 (CPC+ 2017 subgroup). Both subgroups had participated in CPC+ for 3 years by 2019. Almost all providers in the CPC Classic subgroup had previously participated in CPC Classic. 36 Examining these subgroups may provide suggestive evidence on the mechanisms that are driving our results. For example, finding that CPC+ participation was associated with the delivery of high‐value services in the CPC Classic group suggests that CPC+ included additional incentives compared with CPC Classic.

Our study period was from 2013 to 2019. The baseline period before CPC+ was defined as 2013–2015 and our intervention period was defined as 2017–2019. We excluded 2016 from the baseline period since CPC+ was announced in 2016 and providers may have started to change their behavior in preparation for CPC+ starting in 2017 (see Figure 1 for a timeline showing key CPC+ dates and our data availability). Our intervention period goes through 2019 due to the availability of data.

caption.p: Timeline of key dates for the Comprehensive Primary Care Plus Initiative (CPC+) and the availability of data used for analysis. ACP, advance care planning; AWVs, Annual Wellness Visits; CPC, Comprehensive Primary Care; LDS, Limited Data Sets. Source: Authors' analysis of CPC and CPC+ program information, 26 , 31 , 42 Medicare billing information, 7 and data documentation. 37 , 38 [Color figure can be viewed at wileyonlinelibrary.com]

sec.title: Data sources
sec.p: To identify providers participating in the CPC+ partial capitation track, we used the demonstration identifier in the 2017–2019 Medicare Part B claims for a 5% random sample of Medicare FFS beneficiaries. CMS added a demonstration identifier of 78 to claims for evaluation and management services billed by providers participating in the CPC+ partial capitation track.

To construct our outcomes on the delivery of high‐value services and control variables, we used two sets of files: the Medicare Physician & Other Practitioners by Provider files 37 and the Medicare Physician & Other Practitioners by Provider and Service files. 38 The first set includes one record per provider by year and has information on the provider's characteristics, the number of Medicare FFS beneficiaries served by the provider, and the demographic and health characteristics of these beneficiaries. The second set includes one record per year for each provider and each Healthcare Common Procedure Coding System (HCPCS) code that the provider used to bill for Medicare Part B services. Both sets of files identify providers using the National Provider Identifier and include providers who submitted Medicare Part B noninstitutional claims during the year but exclude records that are from 10 or fewer beneficiaries. For example, if a provider billed AWVs for 10 or fewer beneficiaries during the year, their delivery of AWVs is excluded.

We used data from the Area Health Resource Files, 39 data from the National Plan & Provider Enumeration System, and public use datasets from CMS Physician Compare for additional provider characteristics.

sec.title: Outcomes
sec.p: We focused on the providers' delivery of AWVs, ACP, and other preventative services. The other preventive services included flu shots, counseling to prevent tobacco use, and depression screening. We chose these services because they were the most used services in the three broad categories of preventative services: vaccinations, other primary prevention (which includes counseling to prevent tobacco use), and secondary prevention (which includes depression screening). We identified these services in the Medicare Physician & Other Practitioner files using HCPCS codes (see Table A1 for the list of HCPCS codes used for each service).

We constructed a binary outcome indicating if the provider delivered a service in a given year and calculated the number of services billed per 1000 unique Medicare FFS beneficiaries served by the provider in a given year. For our binary outcome, we cannot detect delivery of a service to 10 or fewer beneficiaries since our data do not include such records. For ACP, counseling to prevent tobacco use, and depression screening, we only constructed the binary outcome due to their low use.

sec.title: Control variables
sec.p: In both our propensity score and difference‐in‐differences models, we included the provider's characteristics, such as gender and specialty and characteristics of the provider's beneficiaries, such as their average age and the percentage with chronic conditions (see Table A2 for our list of control variables).

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: To assess the association between CPC+ participation and the delivery of high‐value services, we estimated the following provider‐level difference‐in‐differences model:Yit=β0+β1CPCPlusi+β22017t+β32018t+β42019t+β5CPCPlusi×2017t+β6CPCPlusi×2018t+β7CPCPlusi×2019t+β8Xit+εitwhere Yit is the outcome variable for provider i during year t. 2017t, 2018t, and 2019t are indicators for the first 3 years of CPC+, and CPCPlusi is an indicator for whether provider i participated in CPC+'s partial capitation track. We also adjusted for a vector of time‐varying provider‐level characteristics, Xit. These characteristics may be associated with delivery of high‐value services and improve our model's precision. The coefficient on the interaction terms between the indicator for whether the provider participated in CPC+ and years of CPC+, β5, β6, and β7 are the difference‐in‐differences estimates.

The main assumption regarding the validity of the difference‐in‐differences models is that the intervention and comparison groups would have followed parallel trends in the outcomes of interest after CPC+ even if CPC+ had not been implemented. To increase the likelihood that the intervention and comparison groups would be similar enough to follow such parallel trends, we used propensity score matching to construct a comparison group.

To implement propensity score matching, we first constructed a candidate comparison group of providers. To be eligible for this candidate comparison group, providers must have been in regions not in CPC+, been included in the Medicare Physicians & Other Practitioners by Provider and Service data during our entire study period, had a primary care specialty (see Table A3 for our definition of primary care specialty), and billed Medicare for primary care services in 2015. Using this candidate comparison group and the intervention group, we estimated a logistic regression model with participation in CPC+ as the dependent variable and characteristics of the provider, the provider's Medicare FFS beneficiaries, and the provider's location as the covariates during the baseline period. We used the predicted probability of CPC+ participation from the logistic regression as the propensity score. We matched using one‐to‐one nearest neighbor matching with replacement. We assessed the balance between the comparison and intervention groups on observed characteristics using standardized differences. 40

For our set of outcomes that are indicator variables for whether the provider delivered a service during the year, we estimated logistic regression models. For our set of outcomes that are the count of services per 1000 Medicare FFS beneficiaries, we estimated zero‐inflated negative binomial models. This model fits the data generating process and the distribution of these outcomes best. 41 We report the difference‐in‐differences estimates using marginal effects. For these marginal effects, we calculated the average treatment effect over our entire sample. We clustered our standard errors at the provider level.

To test the parallel trends assumption for our difference‐in‐differences models, we visually inspected trends in the outcomes during the baseline period and regressed each outcome against a CPC+ indicator, dummies for each baseline period, and the interaction between the CPC+ indicator and each baseline period. We restricted the regression to the baseline periods and tested the joint significance of the interactions between the CPC+ indicator and the baseline periods. This test would indicate statistically significant differences in the trends between the intervention and comparison groups. Since ACP was only introduced by Medicare in 2016, we did not observe delivery of ACP during the baseline period and did not test for parallel trends of ACP delivery.

For outcomes that either did not pass visual inspection or our statistical test of parallel trends, we used a difference‐in‐differences model that controlled for differential baseline time trends. In this model, we implemented our main difference‐in‐differences model but also added a variable for the number of years since 2013 and an interaction between the number of years since 2013 and the CPC+ indicator. This model allows the outcomes in the intervention group to follow different linear trends, based on the baseline period, compared with the comparison group. The model assumes that the trends from the baseline period would have continued into the intervention period, absent CPC+, and calculates the difference‐in‐differences estimates based on deviations from these trends.

We conducted sensitivity analyses to assess whether our results are robust to alternative analytic specifications. First, we more robustly controlled for time‐invariant differences between providers and for year effects that affect all providers by estimating a model with provider fixed effects and indicators for all years in our study period. Second, we exclude nonphysician providers (i.e., nurse practitioners, physician assistants, and clinical nurse specialists) since the scope of practice for nonphysicians differs by state. Because our comparison group is from different states than our intervention group, these differences in scope of practice may introduce some bias in our results. Third, we included rather than excluded 2016 in our analysis. Fourth, we excluded providers who were outliers in their delivery of AWVs and flu shots. Fifth, we estimated hurdle models to see whether our results are sensitive to our choice of the zero‐inflated negative binomial model for the outcomes assessing delivery per 1000 Medicare FFS beneficiaries. All analyses were conducted using STATA Version 17.

sec.title: Study population and descriptives
sec.p: Our study population consisted of 4186 CPC+ providers for the intervention group and 96,047 primary care providers not participating in CPC+ in our unmatched comparison group. After implementing propensity score matching, we identified a matched comparison group of 4186 primary care providers. Table 1 presents selected characteristics of the intervention, unmatched comparison, and matched comparison groups (see Table A4 for the results on all characteristics). We found poor balance between the intervention and unmatched comparison groups, with 24 of the 51 observable characteristics we assessed having standardized differences greater than 10. However, we found excellent balance between the intervention and matched comparison groups. Only the percentage of Hispanic beneficiaries and beneficiaries with other race had standardized differences greater than 10.

caption.p: Comparison of selected characteristics between Comprehensive Primary Care Plus providers and unmatched and matched comparison group of primary care providers.

Source: Authors' analysis of 2013–2015 Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) Physician & Other Practitioners by Provider files, 2013–2015 CMS Physician & Other Practitioners by Provider and Service files, 2017–2019 Medicare Limited Data Set Carrier Standard Analytic Files, 2015 Physician Compare public use file, 2015 National Plan & Provider Enumeration System, and 2015 Area Health Resources File.

sec.p: Our intervention group consisted of two subgroups: 1838 providers in the CPC Classic subgroup and 2348 providers in the CPC+ 2017 subgroup. We found adequate balance between each subgroup and our matched comparison group (see Table A5 for the results assessing balance for the subgroups).

sec.title: Unadjusted trends in outcomes
sec.p: We examined trends in our outcomes for the intervention group and the matched comparison group from 2013 to 2019 (see Figure 2). We found increases in the delivery of AWVs, depression screening, and ACP for both matched comparison and intervention groups and stable delivery for the other services. Trends for the percentage of providers delivering AWVs and flu shots and flu shots per 1000 beneficiaries do not appear parallel during the baseline period. On the other hand, the percentage delivering counseling to prevent tobacco use and depression screening and AWVs per 1000 beneficiaries do appear parallel. Our statistical tests indicate that the trends in the percentage of providers delivery flu shots were not parallel during the baseline period (see Table A6 for results from our statistical testing of parallel trends).

caption.p: Trends in the Delivery of High‐Value Services for CPC+ Providers and Matched Comparison Group of Primary Care Providers, 2013–2019. Source: Authors' analysis of 2013–2015 Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) Physician & Other Practitioners by Provider files, 2013–2015 CMS Physician & Other Practitioners by Provider and Service files, 2017–2019 Medicare Limited Data Set Carrier Standard Analytic Files, 2015 Physician Compare Public Use file, 2015 National Plan & Provider Enumeration System, and 2015 Area Health Resources File. We include a vertical red dashed line indicating July 1, 2016, during the year before CPC+ started. The percentage of providers who provided any service excludes providers who provided a service to 10 or fewer beneficiaries since our data exclude such records. CPC+, Comprehensive Primary Care Plus Initiative. [Color figure can be viewed at wileyonlinelibrary.com]

sec.title: Main analysis
sec.p: We found strong and robust evidence that CPC+ participation was associated with a higher likelihood of providers delivering AWVs and more AWVs and flu shots per 1000 beneficiaries. However, we did not find meaningful evidence that CPC+ participation was associated with the likelihood of delivering flu shots, counseling to prevent tobacco use, depression screening, or ACP. Table 2 presents the marginal effect estimates of the association of CPC+ participation with our outcomes. We disaggregate our results by CPC+ year and include results for our difference‐in‐differences model both with and without differential time trends. We bold the set of results that are the best fit based on our visual inspection and statistical testing of parallel trends. We also include the mean of the outcome in the matched comparison group for 2015 as a reference point to assess the magnitude of the marginal effects.

caption.p: Marginal effects of the association of participation in CPC+ with delivery of high‐value services.

tr.th: ME of DinD estimate (SE) parallel trends
ME of DinD estimate (SE) differential trends

td.italic: Services provided per 1000 Medicare Fee‐for‐Service beneficiaries

fn.p: Note: All models controlled for characteristics of providers. We used robust standard errors clustered at the provider level. Bold estimates indicate the best fit model based on parallel trends testing. For our outcomes on the likelihood of delivering a service, we cannot detect delivery of a service to 10 or fewer beneficiaries since our data excludes such records.
Abbreviations: CG, comparison group; DinD, difference‐in‐differences; ME, marginal effect; SE, standard error.

1 For the likelihood of delivering advance care planning, we show the mean in the matched comparison group for 2016 since advance care planning was not covered by Medicare in 2015. In addition, we did not estimate a difference‐in‐differences model with differential time trends since we did not observe more than one baseline year.

Source: Authors' analysis of 2013–2015 Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) Physician & Other Practitioners by Provider files, 2013–2015 CMS Physician & Other Practitioners by Provider and Service files, 2017–2019 Medicare Limited Data Set Carrier Standard Analytic Files, 2015 Physician Compare public use file, 2015 National Plan & Provider Enumeration System, and 2015 Area Health Resources File.

sec.p: CPC+ participation was associated with both a higher likelihood of providers delivering AWVs and more AWVs per 1000 beneficiaries in all intervention years. The effects increased over time, especially between intervention years 1 and 2. The likelihood of delivering AWVs was 6.2 percentage points higher in intervention year 1, 9.4 percentage points higher in intervention year 2, and 13.0 percentage points higher in intervention year 3 compared with the matched comparison group. These are clinically meaningful differences compared with the mean in the matched comparison group in 2015 of 50.6%. CPC+ participation was also associated with 17 more AWV services in intervention year 1, 34 more in intervention year 2, and 44 more in intervention year 3 compared with the matched comparison group. Similarly, CPC+ participation was associated with providing more flu shots in all three intervention years, with the effects increasing over time. Again, these are clinically meaningful compared with our reference point. All estimates were statistically significant at the p < 0.001 level.

CPC+ participation was not associated with changes in the likelihood of delivering ACP or other preventative services. The exception was for counseling to prevent tobacco use. However, this association was not robust to the inclusion of differential time trends.

sec.title: Subgroup analysis
sec.p: Table 3 presents the marginal effect estimates for each of the two subgroups. We found that CPC+ participation was associated with a higher likelihood of providers delivering AWVs and more AWVs in both subgroups, except for AWVs per 1000 beneficiaries in the CPC Classic subgroup in 2017 (intervention year 1). For flu shots, we did not find consistent evidence that CPC+ participation was associated with a higher likelihood of delivering flu shots although we did find evidence of more flu shots per 1000 beneficiaries. The results for counseling to prevent tobacco use, depression screening, and ACP were inconsistent across subgroups, models with and without differential trends, and CPC+ intervention years (see Table A7 for results for these other outcomes).

caption.p: Marginal effects of the association of participation in CPC+ with delivery of high‐value services: subgroup analysis.

td.italic: Services provided per 1000 Medicare Fee‐for‐Service beneficiaries

fn.p: Note: All models controlled for characteristics of providers. We used robust standard errors clustered at the provider level. Bold estimates indicate the best fit model based on parallel trends testing. For our outcomes on the likelihood of delivering a service, we cannot detect delivery of a service to 10 or fewer beneficiaries since our data excludes such records.
Abbreviations: CG, comparison group; DinD, difference‐in‐differences; ME, marginal effect; SE, standard error.

Source: Authors' analysis of 2013–2015 Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) Physician & Other Practitioners by Provider files, 2013–2015 CMS Physician & Other Practitioners by Provider and Service files, 2017–2019 Medicare Limited Data Set Carrier Standard Analytic Files, 2015 Physician Compare Public Use file, 2015 National Plan & Provider Enumeration System, and 2015 Area Health Resources File.

sec.title: Sensitivity analyses
sec.p: Table A8 presents the results of our sensitivity analyses. Our results from our sensitivity analyses are generally similar to our main analysis, indicating that our results are robust to alternative analytic specifications. There were some exceptions, notably that the magnitude of the marginal effect estimates for the likelihood of delivering AWVs decreased and lost statistical significance in our fixed effects model. Nonetheless, CPC+ participation was still associated with increases in the likelihood of delivering AWVs.

sec.title: DISCUSSION
sec.p: This is the first study to examine the effect of an advanced primary care model, CPC+, on the delivery of high‐value services. We find that CPC+ participation was associated with increases in the likelihood of providers delivering AWVs and the number of AWVs per 1000 Medicare FFS beneficiaries. These increases were not only statistically significant but clinically meaningful. These effects increased with additional years in CPC+. These effects were also persistent across provider subgroups even though the subgroups differed in important ways. Providers in the CPC Classic subgroup had previous experience with Medicare advanced primary care models through their participation in CPC Classic. The CPC+ 2017 subgroup had higher levels of AWV delivery prior to CPC+ than the CPC Classic subgroups (see Figure A1 for trends in our outcomes by subgroup). These results underscore the strength of the association between CPC+ participation and increased delivery of AWVs.

We also find that CPC+ participation was associated with increases in the number of flu shots per 1000 beneficiaries but not in the likelihood of delivering a shot. We do not find consistent evidence for the association between CPC+ participation and the delivery of ACP, counseling to prevent tobacco use, and depression screening.

Our results help illuminate which mechanisms were important in changing the delivery of high‐value services. Among the services we examined, AWVs were the only service explicitly incentivized by CPC+. In attributing beneficiaries to providers who are accountable for their care, CPC+'s methodology in 2017 was primarily based on counting which provider delivered the most primary care visits during the attribution window. AWVs and ACP were included in these primary care visits. Starting in 2018, CPC+ changed its attribution methodology by prioritizing the provider who billed the most recent AWV. Because Medicare only allows an AWV to be billed for a beneficiary once a year, billing a beneficiary's AWV would effectively guarantee that a beneficiary would be attributed to the provider, ensuring that the provider would be paid CPC+ payments for that beneficiary. This stronger incentive to bill AWVs starting in 2018 coincides with the large increase in the association between CPC+ participation and billing AWVs from 2017 to 2018. The first year of CPC+ (2017) was associated with an increase of 17 AWVs per 1000 beneficiaries whereas the second year of CPC+ (2018) was associated with an increase of 34 AWVs. Finally, we do not find increases in AWV delivery in our CPC Classic subgroup in 2017 before AWVs were prioritized. This suggests that, aside from prioritizing AWVs, other CPC+ supports and incentives may not have encouraged providers to deliver AWVs beyond what was provided in CPC Classic, which included payments for care management and the opportunity to share in any savings that accrued to Medicare.

These other CPC+ supports and incentives include, first, paying providers a fixed monthly payment for care management. For example, this could have enabled providers to hire staff to help administer depression screenings or counseling to prevent tobacco use. 31 Second, CPC+ recruited health information technology vendors to support providers in implementing health information technology, which could have improved providers' ability to meet the documentation requirements for billing high‐value services. Third, CPC+ established learning systems that, among other things, taught providers how to deliver and bill for these high‐value services. Fourth, ACP was included in the CPC+ attribution algorithm. However, it was not prioritized like AWVs. The other preventative services we examined were not included in the attribution methodology. Finally, depression screening, flu shots, and counseling to prevent tobacco use were initially among a group of quality measures that CPC+ providers could choose to report, but none were explicitly required for reporting as part of CPC+'s performance‐based payments. Our lack of consistent evidence for the association between CPC+ participation and the delivery of ACP, depression screening, and counseling to prevent tobacco use suggests that these other CPC+ supports and incentives may not have been as effective in encouraging their delivery. This is consistent with Huang et al (2022), whose results suggest that providers participating in MSSP were more likely to deliver preventative services that are explicitly included in quality measures assessed by MSSP. 25

Unlike AWVs that were introduced in 2011, flu shots have been known to providers for many decades. This may be an explanation as to why we do not see associations between CPC+ and the likelihood of delivering flu shots but we do see associations with the count of flu shots provided per 1000 beneficiaries. While CPC+ may help address some of the obstacles to providing flu shots, it may not encourage providers who were not providing flu shots to start providing them.

We note a few limitations to our study. First, our results should not be interpreted as causal effects since we cannot be sure that our study design eliminated all differences between the intervention and comparison groups. For example, we find that trends for the percentage of providers delivering AWVs and flu shots and flu shots per 1000 beneficiaries between the intervention and comparison groups were not parallel during the baseline period. These differences may have contributed to the differences in outcomes that we observed, which would bias the effects we find for CPC+. To address these differences, we estimated a difference‐in‐differences model that controlled for differential baseline time trends. In addition, we conducted sensitivity analyses and find that our results generally are robust. Finally, our estimates, especially for AWVs, are large, increasing over time, persistent across provider subgroups. This increases our confidence that CPC+ led to increases in the delivery of AWVs. Second, due to limitations in our data, we focus on the CPC+ partial capitation track, which comprise about half of all participating CPC+ providers. Our results may not be generalizable to all participating CPC+ providers. However, the mechanisms that we identify that may affect the delivery of high‐value services are common to all of CPC+. We would not expect our results to differ for the other half of participating CPC+ providers. Third, because we only use claims for a 5% random sample of Medicare beneficiaries to identify providers participating in CPC+, we cannot be certain we captured all providers in the CPC+ partial capitation track. However, claims billed for a 5% random sample of Medicare beneficiaries should include primary care providers who see more than 20 Medicare beneficiaries, assuming this 5% random sample is equally distributed across primary care providers. In addition, we identified around 7600 CPC+ providers in the claims, which is close to the around 7000 to 8000 CPC+ providers we estimate based on CMS's evaluation of CPC+. 31 Finally, since we selected a subset of all preventive services, our results cannot be generalized to all preventive services. However, because the preventive services we examined are generally used more than other preventive services and we did not find any association between CPC+ and the delivery of counseling to prevent tobacco use or depression screening, we would not expect to find such an association with services that are rarely used.

sec.title: CONCLUSION
sec.p: We find that alternative payment models such as CPC+ can be an effective method of increasing the delivery of high‐value services. Details in designing a model that explicitly incentivize delivery of high‐value services, such as prioritizing AWVs in the methodology to attribute patients to providers, can have important benefits. Even though CPC+ ended in 2021, its successor model, Primary Care First, also prioritizes AWVs in its attribution methodology. We would also expect Primary Care First to increase the delivery of AWVs. The experience of these two models can serve as a lesson to policy makers for considering all aspects of model design as tools to incentivize desired provider behavior, such as delivering high‐value services.

ack.title: ACKNOWLEDGMENTS
ack.p: No funding to report. We would like to thank Richard Pickett for programming support.

fn.p: Source: Authors' analysis of 2013–2015 Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) Physician & Other Practitioners by Provider files, 2013–2015 CMS Physician & Other Practitioners by Provider and Service files, 2017–2019 Medicare Limited Data Set Carrier Standard Analytic Files, 2015 Physician Compare public use file, 2015 National Plan & Provider Enumeration System, and 2015 Area Health Resources File.

caption.p: Statistical testing of parallel trends in baseline period.

tr.th: p‐Value from test of joint significance of the interactions between the CPC+ indicator and each baseline year from 2013 to 2015

td.italic: Services provided per 1000 Medicare Fee‐for‐Service beneficiaries

fn.p: Note: We estimated regressions of each outcome against a CPC+ indicator, dummies for each baseline year, and the interaction between the CPC+ indicator and each baseline year. We restricted the regressions to the baseline periods (2013–2015) and tested the joint significance of the interactions between the CPC+ indicator and the baseline periods. We used robust standard errors clustered at the provider level. Since advance care planning (ACP) was only introduced by Medicare in 2016, we did not observe delivery of ACP during the baseline period and did not test for parallel trends of ACP delivery. For our outcomes on the likelihood of delivering a service, we cannot detect delivery of a service to 10 or fewer beneficiaries since our data excludes such records.
Abbreviation: CPC+, Comprehensive Primary Care Plus.

Source: Authors' analysis of 2013–2015 Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) Physician & Other Practitioners by Provider files, 2013–2015 CMS Physician & Other Practitioners by Provider and Service files, 2017–2019 Medicare Limited Data Set Carrier Standard Analytic Files, 2015 Physician Compare public use file, 2015 National Plan & Provider Enumeration System, and 2015 Area Health Resources File.

caption.p: Trends in outcomes by subgroup. We include a vertical red dashed line indicating July 1, 2016, during the year before CPC+ started. The percentage of providers who provided any service excludes providers who provided a service to 10 or fewer beneficiaries since our data excludes such records. CPC+, Comprehensive Primary Care Plus Initiative; CPC, Comprehensive Primary Care Initiative. Source: Authors' analysis of 2013–2015 Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) Physician & Other Practitioners by Provider files, 2013–2015 CMS Physician & Other Practitioners by Provider and Service files, 2017–2019 Medicare Limited Data Set Carrier Standard Analytic Files, 2015 Physician Compare public use file, 2015 National Plan & Provider Enumeration System, and 2015 Area Health Resources File. [Color figure can be viewed at wileyonlinelibrary.com]
Results for counseling to prevent tobacco use, depression screening, and advance care planning.

fn.p: Note: All models controlled for characteristics of providers. We used robust standard errors clustered at the provider level. Bold estimates indicate the best fit model based on parallel trends testing. For our outcomes on the likelihood of delivering a service, we cannot detect delivery of a service to 10 or fewer beneficiaries since our data excludes such records.
Abbreviations: CG, comparison group; DinD, difference‐in‐differences; ME, marginal effect; SE, standard error.

1For the percentage of providers who provided any ACP, we show the mean in the matched comparison group for 2016 since ACP was not covered by Medicare in 2015. In addition, we did not estimate a difference‐in‐differences model with differential time trends since we did not observe more than one baseline year.

Source: Authors' analysis of 2013–2015 Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) Physician & Other Practitioners by Provider files, 2013–2015 CMS Physician & Other Practitioners by Provider and Service files, 2017–2019 Medicare Limited Data Set Carrier Standard Analytic Files, 2015 Physician Compare Public Use file, 2015 National Plan & Provider Enumeration System, and 2015 Area Health Resources File.

tr.th: ME Estimate (SE) from main DinD model
ME Estimate (SE) from fixed effects models a
ME Estimate (SE) from only including physician b
ME Estimate (SE) from including all years of data c
ME Estimate (SE) from excluding outlier providers d

td.italic: Services provided per 1000 Medicare Fee‐for‐Service beneficiaries

fn.p: Note: All models controlled for characteristics of providers. We used robust standard errors clustered at the provider level. Based on visual inspection and statistical testing of parallel trends, we included differential trends for likelihood of delivering annual wellness visits and flu shots and for flu shots delivered per 1000 Medicare Fee‐for‐Service beneficiaries and did not include differential trends for likelihood of delivering tobacco counseling, depression screening, and advance care planning and for annual wellness visits per 1000 beneficiaries. For our outcomes on the likelihood of delivering a service, we cannot detect delivery of a service to 10 or fewer beneficiaries since our data excludes such records.
Abbreviations: CG, comparison group; DinD, difference‐in‐differences; ME, marginal effect; SE, standard error.
We estimated a fixed effects model with provider fixed effects and indicators for all years in our study period.
We only included physicians and excluded non‐physician providers.
We included 2016 in our analysis rather than excluding the year. Since Medicare began covering advance care planning in 2016, our main DinD model for advance care planning already included 2016.
We excluded providers who were outliers in terms of their delivery of AWVs and flu shots. This sensitivity analysis is not applicable to the outcomes on the likelihood of delivery services.
We report the coefficients and standard errors from the hurdle models since we could not calculate the standard errors of the marginal effects for the hurdle models.

Source: Authors' analysis of 2013–2015 Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) Physician & Other Practitioners by Provider files, 2013–2015 CMS Physician & Other Practitioners by Provider and Service files, 2017–2019 Medicare Limited Data Set Carrier Standard Analytic Files, 2015 Physician Compare public use file, 2015 National Plan & Provider Enumeration System, and 2015 Area Health Resources File.
